topic.title: Chapter 1
topic.shortdesc: Engineer Bob and the steam trainlocomotive Charlie are the best team in the Mid-World Railway Company. Charlie reveals he is alive.

section.title: Meet Charlie the Choo-Choo

fig.title: Charlie and Engineer Bob greet the passing children

image.alt: picture of Charlie the train who has eyes and a mouth, with Engineer Bob in the drivers seat and kids smiling around them

section.p: Bob Brooks was an engineer for the Mid-World Railway Company, on a route from St. Louis, Missouri to Topeka, Kansas. Engineer Bob was the best trainman the Mid-World Railway Company ever had, and Charlie was the best train!
Charlie was a 402 Big Boy steam train, and Engineer Bob was the only man who had ever been his engineer.

Charlie was a 402 Big Boy steam locomotive, and Engineer Bob was the only man who had ever been allowed to sit in his peek-seat and pull the whistle. Anyone else who tried would get burned from the heat coming from the metal and the whistle would not make a sound.

Everyone knew the WHOOO-OOOO! of Charlie's whistle, and whenever they heard it echoing across the flat Kansas countryside, they said, "There goes Charlie and Engineer Bob, the fastest team between St. Louis and Topeka!" Boys and girls ran into their yards to watch Charlie and Engineer Bob go by. Engineer Bob would smile and wave. The children would smile and wave back. Charlie's smile would appear to grow a bit wider.

section.title: Bob's Discovery

fig.title: Engineer Bob searches inside the cab

image.alt: picture of Engineer Bob looking into the body of the train

section.p: Engineer Bob had a special secret. He was the only one who knew. Charlie the Choo-Choo was really, really, alive. One day while they were making the run between Topeka and St. Louis, Engineer Bob heard singing, very soft and low.
"Who is in the cab with me?" Engineer Bob said sternly.

fig.title: Charlie and Engineer Bob talk while on their run

image.alt: picture of Charlie and Engineer Bob happily riding along the tracks

section.p: "Don't worry," said a small, gruff voice. "It is only I."
"Who's I?" Engineer Bob asked. He spoke in his biggest, sternest voice, because he thought someone was playing a joke on him.
"Hardy har-har!" said Engineer Bob. "Trains can't talk! I may not know much, but I know that! If you're Charlie, I suppose you can blow your own whistle!"
"Of course," said the small, gruff voice, and just then the whistle made its big noise, rolling out across the Missouri plains: WHOOO-OOOO!
"Goodness!" said Engineer Bob. "It really is you!"
